ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I tackled different coding assignments in R, focusing on writing clear and concise code. I got some practice with regular expressions and creating model matrices.
I learned how to approach real-world data analysis challenges.
Capstone case studies class synthesizing some of the other courses Ive taken in the major

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course is interesting because you get good practice writing code for a variety of problems, but you generally don't learn too much new material. It was mostly just learning coding tricks from the professor or your classmates and getting familiar with the assignments we worked on.
Could do more advanced case studies like a data analysis course

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that breakout rooms were an effective way to discuss assignments with our classmates as well as to share code and other things through our screens, something that may not have been as easy in-person. Of course many people often mute themselves or shut off their screens so there can be a disconnect through Zoom as well.
The individual sections we had were very very helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course was a good way to practice coding in base R with random coding exercises. If you do not have plans for a senior project/thesis, this is a good alternative to meet the requirement for the major. You won't learn too much new material from this course though.
Yes if you dont have time to write a thesis

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met through Zoom twice each week in our lecture and stayed in the main room to discuss a topic/assignment before moving to breakout rooms where most of the class was spent working on something with other students. We also had meetings in small groups once a week with the professor through Zoom.
